title: RL32914
content: Rising procurement costs for Navy ships are a concern for Navy officials and Congress. The Congressional Budget Office estimates higher funding levels are needed for the Navy's shipbuilding plan. Congress must decide how to address these rising costs, which could impact Navy capabilities and the shipbuilding industry. Options include increasing funding and changing how ships are funded in the budget. Options for addressing rising Navy ship procurement costs include increasing funding, changing funding methods, utilizing multiyear procurement, adjusting acquisition strategies, reducing shipyard overhead costs, improving yard efficiency, building ships without certain equipment, and considering foreign shipyards for construction. Another option is to shift to designs with lower unit procurement costs if other options are insufficient. This report focuses on the latter option. The report discusses options for lower-cost Navy ship designs, including attack submarines, aircraft carriers, and surface combatants. Various reports have proposed these designs, suggesting changes like reducing ship size to lower procurement costs.
